overview: This measure amends the state's medical cannabis laws by updating definitions, repealing the in-person requirement for the provider-patient relationship, and allowing dispensaries to purchase cannabis products from one another. It also establishes a new cannabis cultivator license and creates criminal penalties for unlicensed cannabis operations to combat the unregulated market. The bill appropriates funds to the Department of the Attorney General for enforcement purposes related to nuisance abatement.
appropriations: The measure appropriates an unspecified amount of funds out of the Medical Cannabis Registry and Regulation Special Fund (HB302). These funds are designated for the Department of Attorney General to enforce, and mitigate nuisances relating to, chapter 329D, HRS (HB302). The bill specifies that this appropriation shall be expended by the Attorney General (HB302).

agency_impact: The Department of Health is required to issue cease and desist notices to unlicensed operators and will manage the creation and issuance of a new cannabis cultivator license (HB302). The Department of the Attorney General's Drug Nuisance Abatement Unit is authorized to enforce nuisances related to chapter 329D, HRS (HB302). This new enforcement authority will be supported by an appropriation from the Medical Cannabis Registry and Regulation Special Fund (HB302).
economic_impact: This measure is intended to support the state's legal medical dispensary program, which faces competition from the unregulated market (HB302). By allowing inter-dispensary sales and creating penalties for unlicensed operations, the bill may increase the viability of licensed businesses. Lowering barriers for patients to enter the legal system could also expand the regulated customer base, potentially strengthening the local cannabis industry.
policy_impact: This bill significantly amends chapter 329D, HRS, by creating a new cannabis cultivator license and repealing the requirement that a provider-patient relationship be established in person (HB302). It establishes new criminal misdemeanor offenses for intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly operating an unlicensed dispensary or for platforms that advertise such sales (HB302). These changes reflect a policy shift to bolster the regulated medical cannabis system while actively penalizing the illicit market.
